text:
Excellent recipe.  As recommended, made the following changes, and it turned out wonderfully:
2 T. olive oil,
1 T. melted butter,
3/4 tsp basil,
1/2 tsp salt,
3 T lemon juice,
1 tsp dried parsley,
dash of dill weed.

Instead of wrapping fillets individually, I just put the foil on top of the baking dish.  I also skin fish before marinading (CRUCIAL for lessening fishy taste).  Overall VERY easy.  I make it with rice & serve the remaining marinade to drizzle on rice & fish.

text:
I would like to give this one at least 6 stars. It was very good. I did decrease the olive oil to 1 (one) tablespoon and decreased the salt to 1/2 teaspoon and I can not imagine it tasting any better. I marinated it in a plastic bag and kind of massaged the oil mixture into the salmon and then left it for an hour. I may decrease the pepper a wee bit next time. For you fellow Weight Watchers I calculated the points for a 6 ounce fillet to be 8.5. ***That is the points using 1 tblsp. of oil for the 2 fillets.  Enjoy! Thanks Norma.

text:
We were trying to get into the habit of eating fish for dinner once a week.  We printed out several fish recipes - this happened to be the first one we tried.  We never got around to trying the others.  This has become a staple in our weekly menu. We don't use fillets, we use boneless salmon steaks instead (you'll need to bake for the full 45 mins. if you do too). I add two slices of lemon atop each salmon steak prior to closing up the packets.  Since we prefer to serve this over white rice (sounds odd but is delicious) we omit the parsley so that we're left with a bit of sauce after it's done baking which we then pour over and toss the rice in.  We place the rice on a plate, the salmon on top and serve with steamed broccoli all around.  Once a week every week and it's never gotten old.  I still look forward to it every week.

text:
Oh my gosh!  I NEVER liked salmon before - but this was SO good!!  I doubled the garlic, halved the olive oil, and used 1 tsp dried parsley.  I was worried there wouldn't be enough juice, but after cooking the salmon for 45 minutes, there was plenty of yummy juice!  It was a tad salty (and I love salty food!), so I might decrease the salt to 3/4 tsp next time.  I will definitely make this over and over again - I'm proud of myself for actually loving a salmon dish!  (UPDATE:  I have started using this same method for chicken breasts, and they come out amazing too!!  I love to serve it over brown rice...the juice gives the rice a nice flavor.)

text:
Excellent recipe. As recommended, made the following changes, and it turned out wonderfully: 2 T. olive oil, 1 T. melted butter, 3/4 tsp basil, OMITTED the salt, 3 T lemon juice, 1 tsp dried parsley, dash of dill weed. Instead of wrapping fillets individually, I just put the foil on top of the baking dish. I also skin fish before marinading (CRUCIAL for lessening fishy taste). Overall VERY easy. I make it with rice & serve the remaining marinade to drizzle on rice & fish. I will be making this to serve again for a group of 52 people.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really easy to make! A few notes: 1) There was way too much oil!! The fish was swimming in it! Use only 2 tablespoons and reduce the lemon accordingly if desired. 2) I used pressed grapeseed oil instead of olive oil and it was very light and added a buttery undertone that was nice. 3) I added 1/2 teaspoon of dill and was very glad I did. Next time I will add a full teaspoon. 4) I used half the salt and it was enough. 5) I marinated it only 1/2 an hour and it was plenty. You want to be able to taste the salmon! 6) I used 3 (8 ounce) fillets and baked in a small casserole dish with foil over the top, and a light coating of butter and lemon juice on the bottom. There was still enough marinate for the extra fillet. It worked very well except the marinate mix was about 1/2 inch deep after 20 minutes in the oven, hence the comment about too much oil. Overall an easy, low-mess marinate that I will make again with less oil.

text:
This is a fantastic marinade that really brings out the flavors of the salmon! I do not use the tinfoil method as that tends to take too much time. Instead, I put the salmon in a glass dish, pour this fabulous marinade over the top and broil it. I've found that about 5-7 minutes on either side gets it done.

text:
The marinade was just perfect as written...no need to change ingredients or measurements. If you like your fish steamed rather than baked, this cooking method will work fine. I would have much preferred this simply baked, and maybe finished off by broiling for a few minutes at the end. This steaming method just did not appeal to me or my husband..almost too moist and definitely needing some richness and color that baking/broiling would have created.  Will try again but open roasted.

I read all the great reviews on this recipe so I just had to try it, and boy am I glad I did. It was sooo good!!! All the other salmon recipes that I have are now history, as this is delicious and easy.  I only used 2 tbl. olive oil, 1/2 tsp. each of salt and pepper, and increased lemon juice to 3 tbl. I marinated the salmon for about 3 hours. I had to cut the cooking time down to 25 min. as it was done when I first checked it. Thanks Norma for a wonderful recipe!!

text:
If you’re making this recipe for the first time (as I did last weekend), be careful about some of the posted modifications.     I used two that turned out to be mistakes.
#1 - don’t add melted butter to your marinade!     Once it’s back in the fridge chilling, it’s not a marinade anymore, it’s a blob of thick goo.      
#2 - if you’re using salmon fillets, watch the size - thicker is definitely better.

text:
This fish baked up moist and tasty. Instead of marinading in a glass dish, I put the fish fillets in a big ziploc bag with the marinade, and put them on a deep plate (and just turned the bag over instead of turning the fish itself). That made this dish FAR easier to clean up. I also squeezed extra lemon juice over the fish before serving. Also, I used parsley flakes instead of fresh parsley, and it was still great. Definitely a keeper!

None
text:
This is a wonderful recipe for salmon. In my preparation, I used some hints from other reviewers: used 2 T olive oil and 1 T melted butter, added a dash of dill, only 1/2 t. salt, sprinkle of pepper, and baked it in the same glass pan I marinated the fish. Before adding the salmon, however, I sprayed the pan with butter flavored Pam. Covered pan with aluminum foil for both marinating and baking. No work, no fishy smell, and cleanup of pan very easy. Served with baked potato (since oven was on anyway), perfectly cooked fresh green beans, and a tossed vegetable salad. Gave the recipe to my dinner guest who was duly impressed with our meal. Although the recipe is prefixed by the comment this is a good way to prepare salmon by beginning cooks, those of us who are experienced cooks likewise love simplicity with such great results.

text:
My salmon actually came out just a tad bit drier than I would have hoped for, but I'm still giving this recipe five starts because it had a wonderful flavor and I think the dryness was 'cooker error.' I dropped the temp. on my oven to 350, as it runs a little high, and cooked for about half an hour which I feel was probably about 6 or 7 minutes too long.  Fish was still very flakey and tender, just a litte dry.  I actually forgot to use the basil and sub'd garlic powder for fresh minced (forgot to buy some) and it still had a great flavor.  I also layeted red onion and greed pepper slices on top of my fish which added to the flavor.  I served it over steamed rice and poured the 'sauce' from the fish over the rice as well.  I think I sub'd about half the oil for melted butter because I enjoy a slight buttery taste with my fish.  Great recipe!

text:
Excellent Salmon! I loved salmon and the ingredients in this recipe caught my eye! I used all fresh basil, parsley, garlic, fresh squeezed lemon juice, hawaiian sea salt, fresh ground black pepper and olive oil. I sealed the salmon with all the marinade in an aluminum foil and baked it for 35 minutes, then opened up the foil, turned off the oven and let the salmon finish baking.  My salmon came out so tender, moist and fresh tasting! The herbs and fresh lemon juice really helps to bring out the flavors in the salmon. Salmon is very healthy for you I might add. I served this with brown rice -perfect and healthy!

text:
This is a keeper for sure!  

I noted some of the modifications others made, and I made the following changes:  increased garlic to 4 cloves of pressed garlic, decreased olive oil to 1 Tbsp plus added 2 Tbsp melted butter, decreased basil to 3/4 tsp, decreased salt & pepper to 1/2 tsp, increased lemon juice to 3 Tbsp lemon juice, and I used 1 tsp fresh chopped cilantro instead of the parsley (yes! that was good). I wish I had some dill to add, but I didn't. 

I had two sm filets and marinated in ziploc bag. I placed the filets (with the marinade) in foil just to minimize cleanup, sealed the foil, then placed them in a pan (I didn't have a glass dish) and baked at 400 degrees for 20 minutes, then broiled uncovered for almost 5 minutes.

I served with rice and used the juice to pour over the rice.

OH!  This was good!!!!!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I am a huge salmon fan in general. I make it very frequently. My most important criteria when cooking salmon is that it is cooked all the way through just barely enough. This leaves the salmon INCREDIBLY juicy and flavorful. To be fair, I followed this recipe to the letter (but in the back of my mind I knew that 35-45 min cook time would be WAY TOO MUCH). I was right. The salmon was overcooked to an extreme. It wasn't delicate the way my salmon normally comes out. It was tough, and the only flavor was from the topping, which I ended up scraping off as it just didn't work since it was the ONLY thing you were left tasting. I will definitely not make this again.

text:
This was fantastic!  The only changes I made were that I added a little bit of dill to the marinade and I also cut back a bit on the oil.   I agree with another reviewer that cooking the salmon too long dries it out, so I baked it at 400 degrees for about 15 minutes and then broiled it for 5 minutes to crisp the garlic on top of my fillets. Oh, and I didn't wrap the salmon in foil, I just left it in the baking dish to cook it. It was perfect and totally moist inside.  The flavor was fantastic! My whole family really enjoyed this, even my husband who cringes everytime I tell him I am making fish for dinner.  I will definately be making this again. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Wow! Excellent recipe, LADYBLADE. I adjusted it for 6 servings. I used all the ingredients as suggested in the recipe, except, my parsley wasn't fresh and I used Extra Virgin Olive Oil. As we all do, I tweaked it with a bit more garlic & lemon juice, but not much. I used frozen Atlantic salmon fillets. I placed them in the glass baking dish, covered them with the marinade. I had to use two glass baking dishes. Then I covered the baking dishes with aluminum foil and placed them in the 375* preheated oven. I cooked them for 40-45 minutes. OMG, the taste was amazing! Whether on a bed of lettuce, white, yellow or brown rice this recipe is a keeper. Thanks, LADYBLADE!

This recipe is simple and delicious!!! I would make more marinade because at the end we didn't have that much left for sauce. BTW, put the aluminum foil on the glass dish you are planning to cook in first, then make the marinade in there, then put the salmon in there and marinate in the fridge for 1hr and take it out and just put the dish straight into the oven. Simple, easy, and clean! Less dishes to do :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
(1/12/13)
For 5 servings I used 5 cloves of garlic and around 1/4 cup olive oil.  I used 1/2 tsp. freshly ground pepper and 1 1/2 tsp. sea salt (any more salt would have been too much).  I used fresh basil instead of dried which is a must!
I will add some fresh dill weed next time, maybe 1-2 tsp.
Some of the salmon were done at 20 minutes and the other were done at 25 (I think the 25 minute salmons were still a little frozen in the middle).  I'd like to try parchment paper next time, or possibly just putting them in a 9x13 covered in foil.
Review:

DELICIOUS!!!  I prepared the marinade and placed the fish in it before leaving for work yesterday.  I really don't have that extra hour after work.  When I arrived home, I placed it in the oven and OH MY!!!  My husband, 2 year old and I absolutely loved it.  I served it with my own confetti rice and steamed broccoli. I only used 4 in the marinade and added 2 tbsps on butter when I placed it in the oven.  It was so good that we talked about it for hours AFTER the meal.  Thank you Norma.  This recipe will be used often in our home.

text:
I will start out by saying that I am not a big fan of fish in general but this recipe was Simple and PERFECT!!  I didn't use the measures but rather added ingredients by eye and I didn't have parsley so I used herbs de provance.  At the end, when the fish was pretty much done, I opened up the salmon so it could brown and it gave it that perfect crispy finish on the outside.  I also used quite a bit of oil so it would create a sauce and used that to pour over the pasta that I made to go with it (adding sun-dried tomatoes, artichokes, mushrooms and flax seeds),some nice steamed broccoli and et voilà, wonderful Mediterranean meal in the middle of winter in a Bavarian forest!  :D

text:
This is absolutely delicious. It's my favorite dish to make. It doesn't taste fishy at all.  Cut the fillet you get from the store in half, and marinate in separate tupperware containers (this means you'll half the ingredients for the marinade and put that amount in each container). I marinade for an hour on one side, then flip and marinade for an hour on the other. They turn out PERFECT every time! GREAT recipe!

text:
Maybe it was me, but I cut the cooking time to 20 min and my salmon was still so dry and overdone.  Rule of thumb for fish is 10 min cooking for each 1 inch of fish, measured at the thickest part. I can't imagine how anyone could cook a 6 oz salmon fillet for 45 min and have it at all edible!! Was not impressed with the flavor of the marinade either. Barely noticeable on the fish.  I'm not a huge salmon fan but I've had salmon that is moist, tender and flavorful - this cooking method won't produce that effect.  Will keep searching for a good recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe at my boyfriend's and it was DELICIOUS! However, being health conscious we cringed at the 6 tablespoons of oil and the amount of sodium listed in the nutrition facts. A few suggestions I followed after reading the reviews was: I left out the salt, didn't marinate it, and reduced the cooking time. I used 1 1/2 tbs of Canola oil instead of the 6 tbs of olive oil and we placed it in foil, wrapped it up and baked it in the toaster oven for 25 minutes. It was moist and juicy with TONS of flavor! There is NO need to marinate this recipe because it turns out very flavorful as is. It's hard to find healthy recipes that are EASY to make and tastes great. With a few adjustments, this can be very healthy! It's one of our favorite fish recipes.

text:
I made this recipe last night for a friend's daughter's wedding---for 50 people!  I made the salmon up the day before, in foil packages with about 5 peieces in each, cooking it about 10 minutes less than called for in the recipe. After it baked and cooled, I refrigerated it, in the packages.  At the reception, I reheated it, in the packages (on a cookie sheet) at 350 for about 10 minutes, then put it out in steam table/chafing dish pans on the buffet.  So simple to do and it seemed so elegant as well!  I made brought extra marinade to put over it on the steam tble, but there was plenty in the packages ehen I opened them, so I didn't need the extra.  THANKS!

Display Name:
TexasLady
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is okay, but it just doesn't do it for me.  I was very reluctant to pepper a salmon, but I did anyway.  Pepper, for salmon (and for most fish) IMO, is just too strong.  After adding all the herbs, I think they just killed the flavor.  Salmon is wonderfully flavorful to me, and I thought about not adding all the herbs, but I did anyway.  The recipe I learned from my teenage friends a long time ago after living on the West Coast was much simpler.  For my long time recipe, I just put softened butter all over the salmon, use a heavy sprinkling of parsley all over the meat, lemon squeezed all over the salmon, and put it in foil, close it, bake it for 20-30 minutes (depending on the thickness).  It turns out wonderfully flavorful and everyone is thrilled with it.  No family compliments on this recipe.  I will go back to my own recipe on salmon.

This really was exceptional! Both my husband and I LOVED it. I decided to try and keep it as close to the original as possible the first time. The only thing I changed was reduced the olive oil to 4T and just used salt and pepper to taste. I cooked the salmon for only 20 minutes. I did what another reviewer suggested and cooked at 350 for around 15 minutes then took off the foil and turned it to broil for another 5 minutes. The results were fantastic! It was so moist and the skin and garlic was slightly crispy and oh so delicious. We will definitely making this again and again.

This was fine, but I'd agree with others that it only takes 20 or 25 minutes at 375.  Also, it probably doesn't need the salt or as much oil, and is maybe more tasty with either tarragon or dill instead of basil on the fish.  When you have a leftover piece, the tarragon or dill flavor is very good for a salmon patty or a salmon soup.

Top recipe with changes. I used 1 large fillet about 2 lbs. Cut back on oil. Used 4/5 garlic cloves and added more lemon juice to marinade. Thinly sliced lemon and arranged on top of fillet. I have never marinated salmon longer than 20 minutes and it is always delicious. Cooked in glass dish covered with foil for 30 minutes.

region:

country:
None
text:
Overall, very tasty.  My husband even liked it, and he doesn't like fish (because it usually has a fishy taste). I removed the skin before marinating, and it really cut down on the fishy taste.  In an effort to be healthier, I cut the olive oil down to 2 Tbsp; however, the fish was too dry.  Next time, I increased it to 3 Tbsp, and increased the lemon juice to 2 Tbsp, and it was much better.  I could hardly taste the lemon, so I think I'll add lemon slices on top of the fish while baking, like another reviewer recommended.

Display Name:
dna363636

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a pickier fish eater, I wanted to get more heart-healthy (wild-caught) salmon into my diet, so was looking for an easy, straightforward baked salmon recipe (preferably more savory than sweet, e.g. teriyaki-flavored). This was the first one that I found on Allrecipes.com, so I decided to give it a go. This recipe is fantastic, and so incredibly easy! I slightly altered the ingredient measurements to taste, and added some fresh chopped dill (dried dill will do in a pinch) and covered the entire dish with foil (instead of individually wrapping) as other reviewers suggested. Also, I found that marinating the filets longer than an hour did not adversely affect the taste or the final product at all (it likely improved it.) The flavors meld so wonderfully together and create a fantastic topping and marinade for the salmon. Thanks for providing! This is a definite keeper!

text:
OH...MY...GOD!!! I have never made salmon (or any fish) before and was very nervous to try. I'm definitely not someone who cooks on a regular basis, but this was SO easy, so affordable (I had everything but the salmon & parsley) and absolutely the BEST salmon I have ever had (including restaurants). I was a little low on the olive oil so I included some melted butter - this made it nice and pasty when it came time to transfer to the foil packets. I also added a little bit of dill seasoning. Hands down - the most amazing salmon dish ever! I will definitely be making again - the hubby raved about it! Thank you for this recipe!

text:
WAY TOO MUCH OLIVE OIL. I think half the amount would have been fine. I marinated mine for 2 hours in a pyrex dish covered with foil, then stuck it in the oven at 350 for 30 minutes. I took off the foil and let the top brown for a few minutes. Flavor was pretty good, but subtle. I also did not like that the garlic was still a bit crunchy. I probably won't make this again.

Display Name:
Debi Blair McGinness

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1444763.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is such a versatile recipe.  I was looking for something to do with some steelhead and this fit the bill with a few minor adjustments.  First off, 6 tablespoons of olive oil is WAY too much for only 12 oz of fish.  I cut it down to 2 tbls. and it was plenty.  I used dill weed instead of basil, only because I wanted that flavor, and left out the parsley because I didn't have any.  I also didn't wrap this in foil.  After marinading for about 1/2 hr (in my vacuum sealed marinader), I put it in a baking dish, poured the liquid on to and baked it (uncovered) in a 400 degree oven for 20 minutes.  It came out perfect.

text:
I bought a GIGANTIC hunk of salmon and didn't want to ruin it. I followed this recipe almost exactly since I had more than just 12 ounces of salmon, i had more like 2 pounds!  My only suggestion to make clean-up a breeze is to roll out tin foil over your glass dish, set the salmon on top, fold the foil up at the edges, and then pour the marinade in and wrap. Then you can just marinate it like that for however you like. ( I also put lemon slices on top)  It's delicious and incredibly moist, and I used leftovers for salmon/cream cheese toasts in the morning> DELISH!

text:
I don't just want to be just another person raving about this recipe so I'll tell you why we loved it. The fish comes out very moist and tender and of course full of flavor. Changes I made were for lack of other ingredients i.e. I used 1/2t dried thyme in addition to the other called for spices, wayyyy less olive oil, and only added the lime (had no lemons) juice before cooking. I also had 2 lbs of salmon so I increased the garlic which I grated for more intense flavor and also baked it in a glass dish covered with foil. If your fish is thin you have to cook it less, mine was thick but thin along the side so I folded the thin side under for more even cooking. It is one of the best salmon recipes ever.

text:
Really good recipe! I love fish cooked pretty much in any way and me and my husband really enjoyed this one, but with a few changes, and that's why i didn't give it 5 stars. I followed some of the other reviewer's suggestions, less salt (half the amount), more lemon (3tbsp), 2tbsp of olive oil and 1 of butter (perfect amount) used 2 teaspoons of dry parsley cause i didn't have it fresh, and didn't add dill as other reviewers suggested because i didn't have any. As far as taste goes, excellent, but i cooked our fish (2 40z fillets) for 20 minutes (15 covered and 5 uncovered) and they were way too cooked for us... Maybe with 6oz fillets it would have been fine, i would still try a little less, but i do like the uncovering the fish for the last few minutes in the broiler because it cooks the garlic on top and everything has a better color. I made bowtie pasta and cooked it with some green beans (cut into small pieces 1/2 inch) and a couple of cubes of chicken bouillon, and when this was cooked, i drained the water, added some butter and lemon juice, and served the fish on top of the pasta, with the "sauce" from the fish all over. We really really enjoyed it aside from the fact that it was somewhat overcooked, and we thought it would be real good also with some asparagus instead of the green beans (didn't have them).

text:
My husband and I really enjoyed this salmon recipe.  (It was even worth the trouble it took for me to skin the salmon -- flashbacks to high school biology class were *not* helping there!).  Like several other reviewers, I ended up marinating and cooking the salmon in the same glass baking dish covered with foil.  I think marinating the salmon for the entire hour was worth the wait;  the flavor was extraordinary!  I also added dill and a touch of paprika to the marinade.  The dill flavor was an excellent complement to the fish;  I think I would have missed its flavor had I not added it.  Overall, a delicious recipe, and one I will likely make again!

AB-FAB!!!! I followed the recipe for ingredients, but 'eyeballed' the oil because the other reviewers said it was too much.  I did NOT marinate (didn't have time), put the salmon (a 1.3lb filet) in a foil lined pan, put the ingredients on the salmon- 3 pats of butter on top- slices of lemon over that and covered the baking dish with foil and threw it in the oven for 30 mins.  DELCIOUS!!!!!!!  TOTAL 5 starts from DH- that's actually pretty rare!  Thanks for this great recipe!

My husband and my extremely picky children just LOVED this recipe.  I used garlic powder because I didn't have minced garlic. 2Tbls of oil and 1/2 tsp of salt, 1/4 cup of white wine. I don't want to discourage those of you that do like it...My husband thought it taste so incredible.  He said it was the best salmon he had ever had!

Thanks for sharing, Norma...this is the ONLY way I'll prepare salmon from now on!

userID:
11241520
Display Name:
Joanne Hoschette
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

0
madeRecipesCount:
42
favoritesCount:
44
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6559145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here are my suggestions
1) use less oil..many cut oil to 2-3T
2) many increased lemon juice ...I use 2T to 3T. I use 2 ish T.
3) Salt ..many cut salt to  1/2t.  or 1t.  I use 3/4 KOSHER salt.
3) many added dill..so do I...appx 2 small pinches
4) I NEVER use foil with lemon b/c lemon does react with Aluminum. ( foil or pans) If you really want steamed or poached fish then use parchment packets. BUT baking in a glass or ceremic dish cover will achieve the same results
5) Cook time is way off in my opinion. (and opinion of many others) Do 20 min max. I much prefer baked open over cover and steam method.
6) By all means make extra....then crumble left over salamon over lettace that is spread out on a plate. Top w/ thin slices red onion and thinly sliced cucumbers . Evenly dot with a mixture of  a little mayo ( 1/4 to 1/3 C.)  or yogurt and  few pinches dill & pinch of S & P  .Add another layer if you have enough. Cover with just a few more lettace leaves Cover  the plate w/ plastic wrap. The onion & cucumber will " draw" out their juices into mayo /dill mix and make a FANTASTIC salad by lunch or dinner the next day.  You will be amazed at how this cuts down on snack attacks later ..

Review:

userID:
11259332
Display Name:
EmmLee
isPro:
False

7

40

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3570286.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe, as written, leaves the fish overcooked, oversalted, over-peppered and overly oily. However, the ingredients listed are some of my favorites for salmon. SO, yesterday, when I found my grocery store had large salmon filets on sale, I decided to try it again, with adjustments. I used 1.5 Tbs parseley, 1 tsp dill, 3 cloves of garlic smashed with 1/2 tsp salt, 1.5 tsp dijon mustard, 1/8 tsp pepper, 2 Tbs white wine, 1 Tbs lemon juice and only 2 Tbs (1/8 c) olive oil. I also decided to add 1 med green onion, chopped finely. I mixed all of the ingredients, poured/patted it over the top of the salmon, then let it sit in the fridge for about an hour or so until dinner time. I placed a a few thin slices of lemon down the length of the filet and put it into a 450 degree oven (in an oiled pan!) for about 25-30 minutes (the majority of the filet was a little over an inch thick). It was moist and very flavorful. Thanks for the "bones" of a delicious salmon marinade.

text:
I multiplied this recipe by 1.5 because we had an additional salmon filet. The recipe was delicious! I made a couple changes: I too thought that there was way too much olive oil! In the future, I will cut down to probably about half of the amount recommended. I didn't do the foil packet method, rather I left the filets in the glass dish that I marinated them in and covered with foil (so much less work!!) and that turned out great. I would make again just with less olive oil next time. Great, super easy and quick recipe for the family dinner!

Awesome! Stumbled across this recipe right before making it so I did not have time to marinade but wanted to make it anyway. Instead of marinating I just massaged the mixture into the skin and also just stuck it in a casserole disk with foil over top, so I could spoon the mixture back on throughout cooking and it was wonderful! I can't imagine how much better it could be if I had time to marinade!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is great for when it's too cold outside to fire up the grill. I make this a bunch and it's evolved slightly. The first time I made it, the only thing I changed was to marinate the salmon in the foil packets to begin with, and they came out wonderful and very flavorful. Now, I marinate in the foil, don't use any oil at all except to sprits the foil with to make it non-stick, and use slices of lemon instead of juice set on top. I put the packets together in the morning, let them sit all day and then bake and they taste wonderful. I usually serve with asparagus, yellow squash, and salad for a great and relatively healthy meal! Thanks!

text:
I have been known as hating fish, but I have started making myself eat it as I know it is good for me.  Using this recipe was my first at making a fish dish (my husband normally grills it).  I have now made this a number of times and actually really enjoy it!  My tweaks include: 3 gloves garlic, 4 T olive oil, 1tsp basil, no salt, 1tsp pepper, 2T lemon juice and 1/2 tsp parsley.  Both my husband and kids love it and I make this almost every week! Thanks Ladyblade!:-)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/98780.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I first used this recipe when I was in college, sometime between 1998 and 2001. It's 2012...and I'm still using this recipe. I used it exactly, but with my children now, I change up the procedure in just a most simple way: I lay the fish scales side up, while the fish is marinating, so that the "meat" can receive full flavor. When it's time to bake, I bake scales-side-down, so that now the bottom of the fish gets the benefits of cooking in the herbs and oil. What I no longer do is add the remaining marinade when I transfer the fish to the foil; I transfer the fish to the foil, wrap it up scales-side-down and just bake it. (Otherwise, my little ones say it's too salty.)

text:
Definitely a perfect choice for a first fish dish! Made the changes as recommended by GAYLAF and I left out the dried basil and increased the amount of fresh parsley used.
I think the temp of baking depends on your oven; BF has a reeeaally small oven so I had it baked at 200 degree C. Salmon was loosely wrapped in foil and baked for 40 mins, followed by opening up the foil and baked for another 10 mins. Salmon was moist and well marinated! Definitely gonna do this dish again!

text:
I'm giving this four stars because I also made some changes. I lined the baking dish with foil, but did not seal it; I left it open. I reduced the oil a bit and used dill instead of basil. But the result was astonishing. My husband and I are both originally from the Pacific NW, and grew up loving salmon. I can only get frozen Chilean farmed salmon here in Mexico, and it is not as fatty as wild salmon, so it often turns out dry.  Cooking it this way makes it moist and succulent. We both agreed that this is the ONLY way I'll cook salmon from now on. AND - it's healthy! Thanks, Ladyblade!

Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2011-01-07T14:12:28.71
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
3081203
Display Name:
Can
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
14
favoritesCount:
350
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/621495.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious!!!! I've love salmon, but hadn't tried basil on it before. I was skeptical but not only do I now love salmon even more, I love basil too! I made it this way and it was delicious of course. Then I tried a few other combos and was equally pleased. One of my variations was delicious but don't be afraid to play with the measurements. I don't measure so I'm giving an estimate. I wouldn't go TOO heavy on everything because you may wind up with too much flavor. I used 4 (6 ounce) fillets of salmon (no skin) and rubbed about half to one teaspoon of olive oil on each side. I poured a teaspoon of lemon juice on each side. (Sounds like a lot but isn't) Then I added the following items both to the bottom of my pyrex baking dish and to the top of the salmon after I put it in the dish: (all dried and same measurements for top and bottom) 1.5 teaspoon of basil, 1 teaspoon of oregano, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1/2 teaspoon black pepper, 1.5 teaspoons parsley, 1 teaspoon minced garlic, 1/2 teaspoon dill weed, 1/2 teaspoon mint, 1/4 teaspoon of thyme. Cover with foil. Place in preheated 350 degree oven. Cook for 20 minutes. Take off foil and cook 5-10 more min. uncovered. You can add more salt and lemon juice after baking if u like.

text:
This was the first salmon recipe I've tried, and it was AWESOME! I had never experimented with salmon before and thought hey, if it's this good, I should try some other salmon recipes... I was only disappointed with them.  This is hands down the best.  I usually add some dill weed and though I've tried it with jarred minced garlic, it is much better with fresh.  As other reviewers have said, the amount of oil can be reduced a little bit.  Instead of covering the fillets in foil, I wrap them completely and place them in a glass baking dish.  Usually make with brown rice and steamed broccoli and drizzle the leftover juices over the sides...  WONDERFUL! Boyfriend's favorite dish!

text:
WONDERFUL!  I followed the advice of one reviewer & a few changes.  3T olive oil, 3/4 basil, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp pepper, 2T lemon juice, 1 tsp parsley.  I used 3 fillets too.  Taking the skin off after cooking is a great idea.  Covering the whole dish with foil works well.  I cooked it for 30 minutes.  I also used dried minced garlic (1/2 tsp).  Also, I spooned some of the "juice" onto the fish after cooking.  The combo of flavors are wonderful!  What a smell!  A winner we'll have again!

text:
I was really torn on how to rate this, so here's how it breaks down. I give a 5 star for flavor. Because the flavor was very nice. The over all preparations was very easy. BUT having said that the oil factor in this recipe is outragous. That's my 3 star. There was still way to much oil. I did do it to the T, and after placing the fish on the foil and then spooning the marinade mixture of the top, the oil was just too much. I like my fish lightly buttery just not drench in oil as it cooks, I would recommend that all the ingredients stay the same but cut the oil down by a few tablespoons.

text:
This is my absolute FAVORITE salmon recipe & it's raved about by anyone I make it for.  All I did different is use 4 cloves of garlic instead of 2 (I love garlic & usually double what any recipe asks for) & I used extra virgin olive oil instead of light which I doubt makes much of a difference.  I am also too impatient to marinate it for any more than 20 minutes, but since I pour all the marinade on top of the salmon which I pair with brown rice, it's always plenty flavorful so the extra marinading time really doesn't matter.

text:
TOO SALTY!  I had four 4oz portions of salmon so here are the changes I made. I used 3 cloves of garlic, one tsp of dried parsley (because I didn't have fresh) 2tablespoons of lemon juice, and after reading everyone’s note to cut down on oil... I used 4 tablespoons of oil instead of 6 (I should have paid attention to all the comments about salt, sheeesh) Also, because I was extra concerned with having too much oil, I took the fish out of the marinade and cooked them directly on a wire rack and lightly sprinkled on some bread crumbs. I baked the fillets at 400 for 15 minutes then broiled them another 5 minutes. We all enjoyed the flavour for the fish, however we will not use the recommended amount of salt next time. Even my one year old gobbled it all up!

I was thoroughly impressed with this recipe! I doubled the garlic and halved the olive oil. I didn't have fresh parsley so I used dried. I marinated the salmon in a ziplock bag for an hour. text:
I made this for dinner tonight. My 11yr old son said that it was super good. I rarely make anything exactly as the recipe is written. In making this recipe I made the following changes. I used 3 tbs oil and 1 tbs butter, abt 3/4 tsp salt, and  added abt 1/4 tsp thyme.  I rubbed a small amt of brown sugar on each fillet (on one side)b/4 pouring the marinade over it in a glass baking dish,placed a slice of lemon on each fillet, covered with foil, refrigerated for 1 hour and then baked. Yummy!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Holy Cow, was this a great recipe!!!  I played pretty loose with the specifics per other reviewers suggestions, but it was the easiest and yummiest dinner I have made in... well, maybe forever!  I upped the garlic a little, reduced the oil to approx 2 TBSP, upped the Lemon Juice to 4-6 TBSP (just poured until it looked right), added dill and broiled it for about 8 min per side, turning and flipping frequently to prevent burning.  Then, as suggested I took what was left of the sauce in the glass pan and added it to brown rice and served the Salmon on that.  Magnificent!!!  I will definitely be making this again soon, and for company!!!

While the flavor of the salmon is great, changes really need to be made to the recipe.  There is WAY to much Oil, so I reduced it to 2 Tbsp. Also I reduced the salt to 1/2 tsp, I added a dash of dill weed, added 1 Tbsp melted butter and increased the lemon juice to 3Tbsp. ALSO If you will skin the fish first it will take that strong fishy taste away.

text:
After reading reviews I decided to cut the olive oil in half (with three pieces of salmon)and kept everything else the same. WAY too salty...The flavor was good but the salt was overwhelming. We managed to eat about 1/2 of it. I will make again but cut the salt by AT LEAST 1/2. The only other change I made was I used fresh basil instead of dried. It's a lovely presentation with the basil,parsley and garlic bits and pieces. I also baked mine in the glass pan covered with foil and it was ready in approximately 30-35 minutes at 375. Other than the sale, very good. I served it with roasted broccoli (with Tony's) and a herb/butter pasta rice dish. (one of those in the envelope, it was good).

Display Name:
Mac

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making this recipe.  This turned out very well and was a very easy recipe.  I used 1/2 pound of fresh, wild sockeye salmon and I switched the marinade to 3 tablespoons of olive oil and 3 tablespoons of lemon juice.  Next time I will use 2 tablespoons of each.  I used fresh chopped basil and parsley and also added a small amount of fresh chopped sage and a pinch of dried dill.  I had a little fresh rosemary in the refrigerator; however, I forgot to add a 1/4 teaspoon to the marinade (duh!).  I marinated the salmon for about 3 hours in a plastic baggie and squeezed the mixture about once an hour (8 to 24 hours marinating would be better).  I wrapped the salmon with the marinade in aluminum foil and baked for 40 minutes at 375 F.  PERFECT!!!  I served this wonderful meal with long grain and wild rice and a tossed salad.  A nice Sauvignon Blanc completed the meal.

text:
WOW WOW WOW.  This was just delious.  I marinated the salmon for two hours and my husband grilled the salmon for about 20 - 25 minutes.  We had purchased a piece of salmon with no skin that weighed a little over two pounds.  The only thing different that we'll do next time (when using a piece of salmon much larger then the recipe).  Is increase the quantity of all the ingredients according to the size of the piece of salmon.  For example - 2lb piece of salmon = use 4 times the amount of ingredients.  EXCEPT for the olive oil, I don't think it needed as much as was recommended.  I'd experiment with that.  Plus, I used italian seasoning instead of just basil.  This is a must for salmon lovers recipe box.

Loved it! As usual I changed it beyond recognition but it was so good. I used the marinade as designed but with fresh basil, flat leafed parsley, splash of oil to ensure all is covered and some lemon zest added. Rather than wrapping in foil I baked it open, topped with steamed spinach and garlic (3 cloves steamed with it , apparently too much (so the husband told me but the son thought it perfect..it possibly needed none at all) I then grated a little parmersan on top and baked it at 175C (sorry I don't understand F) for 30min, rest for 5 min. Served with bitter leaf salad and potatoes wedges. (1/4 cut, boiled till just tender tossed with olive oil and salt, baked 45 min at 175C then 5 min at 220C to complete.)

text:
very easy to make and tastes good. I didn't use parsley, because I did not have any. It still came out delicious, served with rice. To avoid more dishes, I made the marinade in a ziplock bag and added the salmon to it. I marinated it in the fridge all night, to bake it the next day for dinner. I lined a glass baking dish with aluminum foil, placed the salmon on it with its marinade, and wrapped the whole thing with the foil, making sure it didn't leak. And voila! No dishes to clean whatsoever! Great recipe, simple and fresh tasting.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My whole fam including the picky eater loves  and asks for this!  I use 2 lbs salmon filet.  4 -5 cloves garlic, 1 -2 tbsp evo, usually forget about the salt.  I use 1tbsp basil & parsley + 2tsp dill.  I don't " marinade" but just pop it all on top of the salmon.  Wrap tight in foil n bake in the oven about 35 minutes.  I tuck the thin skinny ends of the filets under if you have them for more even cooking.  Feeds 5-6

This was easy and delicious. The only thing I did differently was to put the marinade in a Pyrex casserole dish, marinate the salmon in that dish, and then put the casserole directly into the  oven covered by aluminum foil. The garlic on top of the salmon got poached and covered the salmon with little white blobs, which looked odd, but everything tasted great. I'll definitely do this dish again!

text:
I usually bake salmon without covering, but wanted to try a foil-sealed version.  So I marinated 2 salmon steaks with this marinade, and baked one in foil per recipe, and one without cover (for only 20 minutes).  The foil-sealed piece was very moist but, surprisingly, not near as flavorful as the other.  It also lost that nice salmon color.   I will use the marinade again, but just bake the fish without the foil in the future.

text:
Great recipe, don't need to change a thing except bake time! I have made this several times now and have used fresh basil instead of dry on some occasions (tastes just as great!) and after the first try, I now reduce the olive oil by a couple of TBSP. Everyone's oven is different but I find that at 375 degrees, the salmon would be incredibly dry if left to bake for 35 min. I typically start checking at the 20 min mark and have never baked past 25 min.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The marinade is fine, but the time is WAYYYYY too much. 20 minutes at 375 in foil should be plenty. In the back of my mind, I knew this when I saw the cook time, but with such good reviews and some reviews insisting to do the full 45, I gave it a shot. As I suspected, 45 was far too long. The salmon was chewy and getting dry. The next time, I lowered it by 10 minutes and had the same result. Fish cooks very quickly. This recipe time should be cut in half or broiled for 5 or so minutes instead. You'll thank me later!

country:
None
text:
Great recipe! As other reviewers have mentioned, the fish tastes a bit salty when spiced as written and there is more olive oil than necessary, it will go to waste unless you pour it over another dish such as rice. I cut the salt to 1/2 tsp and added olive oil by eye. I didn't wrap the fillets individually with foil and instead put foil over the top of the pan I marinaded them in and baked for 25 minutes at 375C (for thick fillets). Turned out moist and flavorful!

text:
My boyfriend and I love salmon, and we've tried many different recipes but this is by far the best. I had some salmon I cut into steaks so I used that instead of a fillet and lightly poked holes on them before I marinaded them. I also marinaded the salmon in the fridge for a longer time (2-3 hours) but otherwise followed the recipe exactly; It really brings out the delicious taste of the fish rather than add too much flavor to it. My boyfriend and I've found that a lot of the other recipes for baked salmon adds flavoring that interferes with the natural taste of salmon but now were sticking to this recipe whenever we have salmon! So good! Thank you for posting!!

Elliekimmer

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Nice recipe.  Made a few tweaks based on serving for 4:  mixing all of the dry ingredients first, I only used 1/2 cup of olive oil, reduced black pepper to 1 teaspoon, added an extra clove of garlic and added a teaspoon of dried dill and let fillets marinate for an hour.  After baking in the sealed foil for 30 minutes, I opened up the packets, flipped the salmon over and broiled the skin for 5-7 minutes to a nice crisp.  The fish never end up swimming in oil when placed in individual aluminum packets.  Can use leftover marinade to top off each fillet.  Served in individual shallow bowls with brown rice, topped with kale sautéed with garlic, olive oil and lemon and the fillet laid on top.  Huge compliments from the 10 year old to the 80 year old.

text:
This was so good! I followed other reviewers' suggestions on the marinade and decreased the olive oil to 2Tb and the dried basil to 1/2 tsp, but added 1Tb of butter and a sprinkle a dill weed. I marinated three 8oz salmon fillets for 2 hours and cooked it in a small baking dish. It cooked at 375 for 15 mins with the foil cover and an additional 15 mins at 425 with the foil removed. I served this with white rice and roasted asparagus and bell peppers and my girls cleaned their plates! Will definitely add this recipe to our daily rotation.

text:
This recipe was amazing! I've never made salmon that turned out so beautifully! A big bonus was that it was ready in the exact time the recipe said which so many recipes aren't.
I left out the lemon juice (personal preference, as it wouldn't have gone with the sauce we had the salmon with) as well as the parsley. 
I see endless possibilities as far as spices and herbs with this.

Thanks so much for an awesome way to cook salmon!!!

text:
Not a horrible recipe but not good either. I make salmon all the time usually w/ lemon pepper or sweat tangy recipes so I knew not to bake for 45 min which would ruin the fish, always bake salmon at 400 for 20 min exactly unless using steaks instead of filets. This recipe was not very flavorful and just kind of bleh, the oil is useless as would have been better w a tsp of butter instead and the only thing you taste is the garlic. won't use again

This is a great, simple recipe! One thing I alter is I cut the oil out of the baking process: just wrap the fillets/steaks up with the marinade that remains when you pick them out of the bowl (let it drip away a bit), add a tablespoon of water to the foil wrap and presto! Great recipe, LADYBLADE! Thanks!!!

text:
My husband and I celebrated our 44th wedding anniversary today, and I decided to do a nice dinner for us, i.s.o. going to a restaurant.  I opted for this recipe for our main course, and was a bit nervous, as I had never prepared fresh salmon before.  I did use about half the amount of olive oil, and dried parsley i.s.o. fresh, and only baked for about 25 minutes.  We absolutely LOVED the result - it was tender and juicy, with a lovely flavor.  My husband said this is probably the best meal he had ever eaten!  I could give it more than 5 stars!  I hope to make this much more often in the future, bearing in mind that fresh salmon is really, really expensive locally.  Thanks for posting the recipe!

text:
I used to not like salmon at all, but this recipe is divine! A few notes I had: 1) there was way to much olive oil! Decrease it to make it healthier and easier to work with. 2) add some dill weed to the marinade. This is staple (to me) for making salmon. 3) I only needed about 30 minutes of marinating, but the longer you marinade, the stronger the taste will be.  I absolutely LOVE this recipe- it has become one of my most popular meals! I served mine with wild rice and asparagus - sooooo good!!!

text:
This is a great and VERY simple recipe to make. Anybody can make this one, even if you don't know ANYTHING at all about salmon! :) 

Here are some good suggestions.
1) My main suggestion is this: There is WAY TOO MUCH OLIVE OIL! After reading another review, I put in half the olive oil, and even that was a bit too much! 2) I added a teaspoon of dill and it turned out wonderful! 3) I am a garlic-lover and I did two more cloves of garlic than the recipe called for. ;) That always tastes better!! 

I know you'll enjoy this recipe! We had this with steamed broccoli and wild rice. 

This recipe - (despite too much olive oil) - is just perfect and everyone LOVES IT! 

Try it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First off, I'm a vegetarian.  In fact, near vegan for over 20 years.  For the past few years, I've been having a lot of health issues and have become convinced I need to start getting meat back into my diet.  Even back when I used to eat meat, I did not care for seafood.  But, trying to improve my health, I'm starting off slow, trying to eat 1 an per day and 2 oz of some kind of free range meat.  So I went out and purchased about a pound of wild caught salmon and looked for a recipe for it and found this one.  I read other reviews and cut the oil back to 2 Tablespoons.  A full teaspoon of salt seemed like a lot, so I cut that to 1/2 teaspoon.  While I'm never going to love seafood, this recipe was good enough that I ate a little over my goal (2.5 ounces of the fish) and instead of just giving all of the remaining fish to my husband to eat, I put aside another 2.5 ounces to eat later this week.  Thanks for a good recipe that made eating fish palatable for me.  I was initially worried that it was way too much garlic, but it wound up being just perfect.  My husband hasn't tried this yet, or else I'd let you know what his opinion is as well (although he loves fish and meat, so can't imagine he would have anything negative to say).

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty! Followed all the portioned ingredients as directed however used a huge slab of salmon from Costco that I pre-cut into pieces (Approx 50 oz total...  or 1.5kg)...  Was concerned when I was marinading that I didn't have enough liquid so threw in a bit of white wine before cooking (about 1/4 cup) just to add moisture and sprinkled with some dill and lemon pepper.  Had marinaded in a casserole dish that I simply covered with foil, 375 for 30 min was perfect.  There was more then enough juices afterwards to put on rice and I probably didn't need to add the wine...  I can understand why it would be way to much marinade for only 2 X 6oz pieces!  Served with a Pinot Gris and got compliments all around!  Will definitely make this again!

city:

country:
None
text:
Disclaimer: I hate fish. I have never in my life liked fish. I've tried to make fish many times, and I still never like it. That said, I LOVED this. I followed the recommendations and doubled the garlic, reduced the olive oil to 2 tbs, reduced the salt in half (and that was even a bit much), and added a teaspoon of fresh dill. Marinated for an hour, then covered the casserole dish in foil and baked for 30 minutes. It came out perfectly flaky and not too soft, and so full of flavor. I ate a huge piece and was practically licking my plate! I'm not sure what made a fish-hater like me want to try this recipe, but I'm so, so glad I did. I'd give it 10 stars if I could!

text:
Made this last night using salmon and talapia and it was AMAZING!!!! I maranated all the fish together in a glass dish as directed. I used just a little less olive oil but measured out everything else. I baked the fish in foil all together laying it out flat in a 9x11 glass dish. Next time I will just bake it in the dish and cover the dish with foil to see if it turns out the same. I served this with long grain white rice and steamed veggies. I just topped the rice with the servings of fish and then poured the extra sauce over all. It is DELISH!! My mother in law, hubby, son. and grand kids all loved it!! I will make the recipe once a week because it's that good!! Thanks for the recipe LadyBlade!

Display Name:
Luna

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/300144.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I made this dish my boyfriend cleaned his plate for the first time EVER!  This is also the first time I made salmon.  I didn't change the recipe much (just added extra garlic because we love garlic, used 1 tsp. of dried parsley because I didn't have fresh and unfortunately only had the lemon juice in the little plastic lemon-shaped container).  I didn't have time to marinate so I split the mixture between 2 pieces of salmon in individual sealed foil packets and it still turned out great.  I will definitely be making this dish again and again!  I will be trying other reviewers' suggestions on reducing the salt and oil next time.  I will also use fresh lemon juice a/or slices and limit baking to no more than 35 minutes.  Thought that 45 mins. may have been a slight bit too much.  I served this up with white rice and broccoli.  All in all a great dish!
UPDATE:  Tried using frozen salmon and it did not come out as good.  Used a baking dish another time and I prefer the foil method.  I think the juice of a whole lemon works better too.  30-35 minutes cooking time seems ideal.  I tried 25 minutes once and the salmon could have stood to cook longer. I don't think I will reduce the salt either.  I did so when I tried the marinade on chicken and it definitely needed the regular amount in the recipe.

Love this recipe.  It is so quick and easy.  I don't use the precise measurements, just toss it all in a ziploc bag, mix it up, and then put the salmon in the bag and let sit for about an hour or so.  I don't wrap the salmon individually, instead I put it all in a glass dished and loosely wrap with aluminum foil.  I bake for about 25 minutes and its done.  Perfection every time!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Let me start by saying that I am not a big fan of salmon, but this was tolerable...almost good!  After following other reviewer's suggestions, I used 2 Tbsp EVOO, 3/4 tsp. basil, 1/2 tsp. salt, scant 1/2 tsp. pepper, 3 Tbsp. lemon juice, 1 tsp. parsley, 2 cloves garlic, and about 1/4 tsp. of dill.  The only thing I would change for next time is to decrease the lemon juice to  2 Tbsp, as I found it a bit too 'lemony'.  Removing the skin before cooking, as someone suggested, really did seem to reduce the 'fishy' taste!  Thanks for that tip!

text:
I've never been a fan of salmon, but this recipe changes everything. It's so simple, but the marinade adds such a wonderfully refreshing flavor to the salmon. I left out the parsley since I didn't have any on hand, but the salmon was delicious just the same. I baked one small fillet for 35 minutes, and that was the perfect amount of time for a moist, flaky finish. I highly recommend this recipe if you want a light and flavorful salmon dish. Delish!

text:
Yummy!  This is very flavorful salmon. It goes great on top of a romaine salad w/ lettuce, tomato, cucumber, parmesan cheese, balsamic vinegarette  and a side of w/ lightly buttered and herbed toasted flatbread.   I used 1 tsp. of Morton's light salt and added 1/2 tsp. of Ms. Dash Extra Spicy because I watch my sodium but want to keep flavor.  I also accidentally bought lime instead of lemon juice at the grocery store and it still came out well.  There was a lot of oil in the pan at the end, so you may be able to cut back.  This one is a keeper!

text:
I tripled this for a 2+ lb salmon fillet.  Following other suggestions, I reduced the olive oil to 2 tbsp (i.e. 6 tbsp for my tripled recipe), removed the skin from the salmon before marinating, and baked the salmon, covered, in the same baking dish in which I had marinated it.  I didn't have fresh parsley, so I substituted 1/2 tbsp (1.5 tbsp in my tripled recipe) dried parsley.  This was a big hit!  It was very peppery, though, so I will probably halve the amount of black pepper next time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good!  I gave it 4 stars only cause I tweaked it to what other reviewers suggested.  But the result was definitely 5 stars, eventhough I only marinated it for 10 minutes.  I will definitely marinate longer next time though.  I made 4 portions but equivalent for 2 portions of salmon the changes I made were 1 T olive oil, 3/4 tsp basil, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp black pepper, 3 T lemon juice and 1 tsp dried parsley, oh and 1/2 tsp dried dillweed. After marinating for only 10 min. I pan fried it in a little more than 1 T of butter.  I flipped it once and in total cooked it for about 15 min.  I sprinkled more black pepper and dillweed on it when cooking and it turned out sooo good!  I am so happy that I found a way to cook salmon now that is not just butter, salt and pepper.  I will marinate it next time for 30 min to 1 hr, but even 10 minutes of marinating was delicious!!

This is a light marinade that allows the taste of the salmon to come through.  It is very simple and delicious.  I made the following changes:  4 cloves of garlic, 4 tablespoons of olive oil, 1 tablespoon of butter, 2 tablespoons of lemon juice, 1/2 teaspoon of salt, and 1/2 teaspoon of ground pepper.  I also covered my entire baking dish with foil rather than wrapping individual pieces.  45 minutes was perfect for my one pound cut of salmon.

So easy!  I made some changes when I was in a hurry and out of some ingredients that I guess it could be a whole different recipe.  Instead of olive oil, I used 4 T of melted butter, 1 t dried garlic powder, and omitted the parsley. Instead of marinating, I just dipped the salmon in the mixture for about 1 min., then dipped it in bread crumbs seasoned with salt and pepper, then baked according to the instructions.  Turned out very good and my kids ate it!

text:
AWESOME FOR 1st TRY!!! This is my first attempt at making salmon. I went exactly by the recipe EXCEPT that I used dill (a couple of dashes) in my marinade. I placed the filets in a glass dish and marinaded for 30 min. turning every 5 min. Before I put it in the 375 oven, i melted 1tblsp unsalted butter with a couple dashes lemon juice and added it to the glass casserole dish(making sure I rubbed the filets in the butter and marinade mix). Covered in aluminum foil and baked @375 for 35 min. I served w/softened baby carrots & butter & herb rice. My fiance and I LOVED IT!! AWESOME RECIPE!!! I can't wait to make it for my friends and family!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great marinade for more than just salmon. I've tried this with tilapia, and rock fish and it is delicious. A few variations I've made is to use fresh basil and lemon zest. I poach the fish in parchment paper (en papillote) instead of foil. For those of you who try to avoid aluminum, this is a great alternative. I love garlic and herbs so I adjust the quantities to my liking. This recipe is pretty fool proof so have fun with it and modify it to your tastes. I've added red pepper flakes and capers. I've even made a pesto out of all the ingredients just to switch it up. It is the first dish I ever cooked for my husband (when we started dating) and he still loves it. To this day he says it's his favorite salmon. Enjoy!

Made this last night. It was incredibly easy to put the marinade together. I made this salmon for my boyfriend's birthday, and we both loved it! As was suggested by other reviewers, I used only 2 tbsp of olive oil. This was very good quality garlic flavoured olive oil, and as a result I did not need to use the cloves of garlic. I also used slightly more lemon juice, and ground some fresh ginger root into the marinade.  I actually used 3 fillets of salmon with this recipe (just in case we'd want seconds.. which we did) so there wasn't as much of it. As a result I rubbed the marinade well into each fillet. Then I stacked the fillets into a plastic bowl, wrapped the bowl in a plastic bag and marinated it in the fridge for about 3 hours. After the 3 hours I wrapped the fish in aluminum foil and baked it on a cookie sheet for the given amount of time.  The flavour really penetrated the fish all throughout... it was delicious, will definitely make it again!

text:
Delicious! I just eyeballed the olive oil....... and also thought it sounded like too much salt so I put in 1/2 tsp. and it was plenty. Next time I might cut back on the basil, esp. when I add some dill weed. More lemon juice is also good. I do think it would be better to marinate for at least 3 hours or even overnight. I let it marinate for only an hour and it was great, but I could tell the flavors had not gone entirely through. I baked 25 min. and guessed 20 would have been OK. I used small boneless pieces.

text:
I made this recipe for my mother (new to a restricted sodium diabetic diet), who is missing her salt.  I followed it exactly with the 3 following exceptions: 1. I used no salt at all 2: I cut the olive oil to 3 tablespoons (re: comments in other reviews) 3. I marinated the salmon for 3 hours (see above).  I cooked it at 375 for 30 minutes - next time if I marinate that long, I will check it at 20 minutes.  We both loved it and neither of us felt it needed any additional seasoning.  This was easy and while salmon has been one of my lesser favorite fish, I certainly will fix this many times again.  Thanks, LADYBLADE.

text:
This was really delicious although I don't think it needs to be cooked for that long, I guess it depends on your personal taste. Also I did what some of the other reviewers did and just put the salmon in a baking dish and tightly wraped with foil. As far as the ingredients are concerned I just put in what I think is appropriate, what feels right. Combining corriander with the parsley is nice too. I'm going to make it again tonight as I got some nice fresh salmon this morning at the Gleadle Street market in Richmond, Melbourne, Australia. It goes really well with mashed potato and green beens. Make sure you save the juice out of the baking dish to pour over salmon and especially the mashed potato. Bon Apetit.

text:
My boyfriend and I thoroughly enjoyed this recipe.  We used a 1.5 lb salmon filet from the butcher and still only used about 2.5 T olive oil with a bit of dill and extra lemon juice.  I also sliced lemon and placed it on top of the salmon as it marinated for 2.5 hours.  Rather than broilig, we took advantage of the beautiful day and grilled the salmon (10 min. per inch of thickness).  It was very simple and delicious.  Served over brown rice and a side of grilled asparagus, zucchini, squash, green/red peppers and mushrooms.

text:
I had planned to make this as written, and then decided I wanted to use my oven for sweet potato fries....so I ended up using this marinade w/the following modifications, due to tastes/reviews:  2 T. olive oil, 1 T. melted butter,1/2 tsp salt, 3 T lemon juice, 1 tsp dried parsley, tsp of dill weed, and a tsp of garlic salt. I didn't have much time to allow them to marinade (~15 min) before I sauteed them on the stove in heated olive oil.  They took about 20-25 mins to cook stove top (at the end, I ended up flaking one stubborn piece into pieces to hurry the process...I actually found i preferred it this way and will do it like this in the future).  I am looking forward to trying this in the stove in foil packets, as well.  Thanks for a great recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
catholic soup queen
isPro:

followersCount:

madeRecipesCount:

favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was given a 5 star rating by my DH whose idea of eating fish, is well ah hm...battered and fried. Perfect recipe for low carb dieting and the taste is superb. I skipped a few steps and it was still awesome. I lined a glass baking dish (long enough for my fillet) with excess non stick foil, combined olive oil, herbs, garlic and added some butter, too. Heated in microwave to melt butter, poured half over one side of the salmon fillet, right over the foil, and flip the fish and poured the rest over the other side, closed up the foil and popped it into the oven while preheating. So, I skipped the marinating "2 hrs". It was fabulous and I highly recommend this for even those who are squeemish about eating fish. Salmon is never a fishy-fish, unless it is not very fresh. Buy your salmon fresh when you are near the sea or buy it flash frozen, so that the integrity and freshness aren't lost in transit.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, until last week, I had never had or prepared home-cooked salmon fillets. :) We're trying to get more Omega-3's, and having more salmon is a wonderful way. I cut the olive oil down to about 2 TBS, used 1 TBS of melted butter (as recommended by other reviewers!), and omitted the parsley. It was fabulous! I've made it twice, once with lemon (recommended!) and once with lime juice as we ran out of lemon (and it tasted a little weird). I definitely recommend this salmon with the skin removed and with lemon! A shake of dried dill is also a nice addition. I have problems with overcooking the fish, maybe that'll get better with time. Thanks so much for sharing, Norma! Our four-year-old loves this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yummy! I skinned the fish put it in the bag with the marinade: 2 cloves garlic, 2 T olive oil, 3/4 t basil, 1/2 t salt, 1 t pepper, 3 T lemon juice, 1 t dried parsley.  Dumped it all in a glass dish & covered it with foil & baked for 35 mins. After putting fish on the plates, I added 1 T melted butter to the sauce & poured it over white rice. Rosemary carrots from this site on the side. Very good, no fishy smell or taste. I wanted to start serving fish once or twice a week to add some healthier meals to our menu & this was just wonderful. Thank you.

I loved this recipe!  I had been trying out different baked salmon recipes and none have compared to this one.  I used a little less salt and pepper and instead a pure garlic I used garlic powder and it came out absolutely delicious. My boyfriend also loved it and wants me to use this recipe for salmon all the time.  This one is definitely a keeper!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I absolutely love this recipe. The salmon turns out sooo moist and flavorful, but still tastes like salmon. I generally find that it takes 30 mins to cook with a thick filet... if you're using a thin cut, cut the cooking time almost in half. You want your salmon to be moist and "pink" in the center... not light. I would also say that if you like fish, this is best with a thick cut.... the herbs are wonderful as a "coat" but not as the primary flavor.

country:
None
text:
This is definitely a keeper.  I marinated the fish (flesh side down/skin side up)in a pyrex baking dish in the fridge...without turning it.  To bake, I covered the dish with foil and cooked for the full 45 minutes.  It turned out great and was sooooo easy.  The only change I will make next time will be to cut out the salt in the marinade.  With the lemon juice it didn't need the salt.  As is it was a little too salty.  But all in all a wonderful addition to my recipe file!

This was a very tasty dish, I tripled the recipe because I had to serve 6 people.  I did cook it a little too long, but it still came out excellent.  Just be careful not to cook it longer than 40 minutes because then it begins to dry out.  A variation I did add for my husband is about a tbsp of juice from my husbands banana peppers to the marinade and about ten banana peppers to it while cooking.

text:
I made this on Tuesday for our first month  anniversary, and my husband loved it!  He said it was the best dish I've ever cooked.  I served it with the Rice-a-Roni rice pilaf and asparagus.  Asparagus was steamed (boil water in a pot, leave the asparagus in there for 3 minutes), and once drained, I melted margarine on top.  I also left it in the oven for 40 minutes, and then broiled it for 5 more minutes.  He absolutely loved it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Almost perfect, so I played around with this one for a few months. I cut down on the basil.  Added 1/4 cup of wine and 7-8 dashes of Franks Red Hot Sauce.  Left out the salt, added 4 pats of salted butter to the top of the salmon.  After baking, I pan fried it searing hot for 3 minutes with a spash of the marinade.  Perfect!  If you like this as a meal, try making it an appetizer.  Put spoonfuls of the cooked salmon on crackers and drip a little of the sauce it cooked in.  You'll run out fast!!!

Excellent recipe. I added a little more herbs to my take. Paprika, pepper, sea salt, oregano, basil, and Italian seasoned bread crumbs for a little crunch. Lots of lemon zest and juice as well. Served with steamed broccoli and steamed brown rice with infused vegetables. I used avocado cold pressed oil for the marinade and cooking. Thanks! Buen Provecho!

I followed the recipe except I sautéed the salmon in olive oil and butter after the marinating. I drizzled the fish with the extra sauce when it was almost done. The flavor was light but pleasant, went well with salmon. Steaming in a foil pouch, I would think, would lessen the flavor even more.

I literally loved this!!!  I had to skip marinading due to time constraints and hungry family, but flavor wise it was perfect.  I dont think basil would have made this better, as another poster suggested.  Whenever I serve fish I put a slice of lemon on the plate, and of course there is always salt and pepper.  I like to use the least amount of salt as possible when cooking, because we have a lot of different dietary needs here.  But everyone is free to add what they want at the table.  Made wild rice and fresh steamed broccoli.  Beautiful healthy meal.

I was looking for something different than the usual seared salmon and for something to bake, instead. This was a home run! I followed the recipe to the letter and it turned out perfectly. While I had the fresh lemon, I did use  powdered garlic and dried parsley, and regular olive oil since they are what I had on hand. I admit this was too salty for me, so the next time I may either greatly reduce or eliminate the salt altogether - it is always easier to add than take away.  The bake time I used was 40 minutes, and it produced perfect portions. My husband loved it, so this is a definite keeper.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoy this recipe but I do feel its more a steamed flavor than a baked flavor, if that makes sense. Its always really wet when it comes out, but absolutely delicious. I find this recipe to be palatable and flavorful without ruining the fish flavor by drowning it out and it leaves the fish with a nice texture still at the end. I use this recipe while making an whole side of salmon (fresh caught we cut up ourselves) and we leave the whole side but I still find that the bake time is TOO long. So I would keep a close eye on the fish while baking this because with it all tucked in the foil like that, I find it bakes up really nice within a half hour at the most, even on a big thick fish.

Easy and delicious! I made a few changes. I used 3 T of melted butter, 2 T of olive oil, and 2 T of lemon juice, and half the salt. I left the other ingredients the same. I marinated it in a ceramic dish and covered it with the glass lid. When time was up and I left the dish out on the counter to come down to room temperature a bit, I put the covered dish in the preheated oven.I left it in for 45 minutes. Everyone loved it!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7073532.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We had the fish for supper yesterday, and it was delicious; we had the left-overs today, and it was even more flavourful. I used a whitefish instead of salmon, and cut back on the olive oil and garlic, as suggested by others. I also placed a slice of lemon on each fish fillet.  I didn't wrap the fillets separately, but simply covered the entire baking dish with foil.  I found the whitefish didn't need quite as long as suggested in the oven since the fillets were quite thin. The final result had a lightly spiced, lemony flavour, but not so much as to bury the fish's flavour.  The best part, though was the juicy flakeyness of the fish.  I highly recommend this recipe.

userID:
3004713
Display Name:
Virginia Wichman
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
129
favoritesCount:
415
recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7281893.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just can't help myself.  I find a recipe that is the idea of what I want and then make it my own.  I had Rock Fish instead of Salmon so used that, 3 garlic cloves instead of 2, avocado oil instead of olive oil, reduced salt to 1/4 tsp., juice of one medium size lemon and 1 tblsp white wine.  Placed fish in metal baking dish covered with aluminum foil and coated it with about half of the marinade. Refrigerated for 30 minutes, then flipped the fish and put the rest of the marinade on the fish. Baked the fish (without any covering) at 375 for about 20 minutes or until the fish reached an internal temp  of 140 degrees. It was perfect!  BF said I could make this anytime. We ate it ALL!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I dropped the oil down and increased the lemon (Real lemon) as others suggested, and used roasted garlic  and fresh basil and parsley then marinated and baked it in the same glass dish.  I baked it 20 mn covered then uncovered for another 10.  The fishmonger instructions said to bake Salmon at 425 for 8-10 mn, but certainly to an internal temp of 145 degree so that was my true guide and it was perfectly moist and flaky.  I thought it could take more lemon and garlic but that could be my taste.  I will absolutely use this again.  I would give it 5 starts but those recipes usually have cream in them...

Display Name:
mihart.m

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a non-fish lover, this recipe allowed me to eat the whole filet. It was tasty. Not mind blowing, but the flavour was there. I will keep coming back to this recipe. It was easy to prepare, I did not make any changes to the marinade, however I did change the cooking method. Steamed fish just does not appeal to me . I heated my cast iron pan on med high, added oil when it was good and hot so the oil smoked. Cooked the flesh side down for 3 minutes with the marinade poured in. Flipped gently onto the skinside and cooked that for 4 minutes. Added melted butter to the top while the skin was crisping to keep it moist. Turned out great.

city:

country:

text:
I loved this healthy but tasty recipe. First time making salmon by the way and noticed the white milky substance but it was safe and it happens a lot so I researched minimally to see if it was ok. This is what I found:
  We hate to be the ones to tell you this, but the white stuff oozing out of your salmon is your fault. It happens to everyone, and it looks gross. The good news is that it doesn’t have to be that way and we’re going to tell you how to fix it.

First, let’s get to the bottom of what that stuff is. The totally harmless, but wholly unappetizing white gunk that seeps out of salmon filets as they cook is just coagulated protein — also known as albumin. (To clarify, the correct spelling is albumin with an “i.” You may have also heard of albumen, with an “e,” but albumen is the term for egg whites. They’re two different things.) This sounds bad, but it’s absolutely safe. Albumin gets pushed out of the muscle fibers of fish as it cooks, coagulating at the surface. This will happen to all salmon, no matter what you do. It has been hypothesized that the way you cook salmon — how fast and how long — causes albumin, but this is not true.

America’s Test Kitchen tested the cooking theory AND talked to Donald Kramer — a professor of seafood science at the University of Alaska — and concluded that the way you cook fish will not stop albumin from collecting at the surface. While they did see some more albumin with salmon that was purposefully overcooked, it collected on all t

text:
This was a truly flavorful dish!
I marinated the fish, 7 portions, skin side up for an hour in the fridge uncovered, and then flipped it skin side down just before I placed it in the foil, and poured the remaining marinade over the fish. I had to use a half sheet pan for so many portions :)
I did think 40 minutes was a long time and was worried about over cooking, but it was moist and flaky.
This is now a new favorite.  
Thank you LADYBLADE!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
SO DELICIOUS!! I followed the advice of reviewer ROUVER, with  the only adjustment being 1/4 tsp salt, instead of 1/2 tsp, since I was only making one filet for myself. After marinating for an hour, I seared both sides of the filet in a cast iron skillet (two minutes per side), then returned it to the glass pan and covered it with foil. Baked for 30 minutes. Removed foil then broiled on high for 5 minutes. Done! I ate my filet with jasmine rice and poured the remaining juice over top. When I make this again, I'll probably only use 1.5 tbsp lemon juice and add more butter. It's my first time cooking fish of any kind, and this recipe made it super easy. Definitely a keeper!!
