This is a really easy recipe.  I do agree with ROUVER with the changes:
Excellent recipe. As recommended, made the following changes, and it turned out wonderfully:
 2 T. olive oil,
 1 T. melted butter,
 3/4 tsp basil,
 1/2 tsp salt,
 3 T lemon juice,
 1 tsp dried parsley,
 dash of dill weed.
I did put mine in a glass container with the foil and it came out great. You could also do this on the BBQ in foil.

I'm getting ready to make this for the second time.  I had never baked salmon before, so I searched this site for a recipe using ingredients I have on hand.  That's how I decided on this one.  It did NOT disappoint!  I baked 3 fillets and followed the recipe exactly as stated.  I thought it was delicious and my daughters each ate a fillet and loved it.  I do think I could have made 4 or 5 fillets in the amount of marinade but it just depends on how much spice you like.  I personally like the amount called for.  Tonight I am trying this with a little less olive oil and a little more lemon juice to try and make it a little lighter.  Great recipe!
Review:

country:
None
text:
Absolutely amazing!! I will definitely make this again for myself and guests. I followed the recipe as much as I could, using what I had available for 1 sockeye salmon fillet. Instead of fresh herbs I used dry herbs, I ran out of garlic so I used garlic salt (1tsp, will probably cut it back to 1/2 tsp next time), used fresh ground pepper, and did not include dill. I read the other reviews and decided to bake the fillet in a dish and cover with foil at 400 degrees for 15 minutes. Then I marinated the fish in the pan juice and broiled on high for 8 min. It was delicious and if I had fresh ingredients it would have been a 10-star recipe!

text:
Awesome flavor!  My first time making any sort of fish, and given how well it came out, I will definitely make this again!  I made triple the original recipe, but still 20 minutes-ish (forgot to set a timer) was enough to bake the fish all the way.  I just baked them all together in the glass dish with a sheet of foil over top rather than doing pockets for each one.  

I went with most of the suggestions and reduced the salt and upped the lemon juice.  I cut the oil by half, and substituted part of that with butter to keep the oil from smoking, but I think I'll try reducing the oil/butter even more next time.  Just seemed like there was too much.

text:
Wonderful recipe. As many suggested, I reduced the olive oil to 1 to 2 tablespoons (I forgot to do this once and 6 tablespoons was just way too much oil. I didn't even feel comfortable pouring the sauce over my rice as it was too oily to eat) and instead of wrapping it in tin foil, I put the filets in the baking dish, covered in marinade and then covered the dish with aluminum foil.  Very simple recipe and comes out great!

text:
I also decreased salt to 3/4tsp, added sliced onion and lemon rounds and a few small dabs of unsalted butter while decreasing oil to 2 Tablespoons. I used half grapeseed oil and half olive oil...as I was running low on EVOO. Skipped foil packets to bake in glass pan covered with foil.
Probably ranks in top three salmon recipes I've ever made. I also used a bit of this marinade to brush across my asparagus that I put on top rack for 30 minutes at same cooking time and they were just beginning to roast but tender. Amazing!!

It was way, way too salty for me- I would use /recommend 1/2 a teaspoon instead. I did not have fresh parsley so I substituted 1/2 teaspoon of dried parsley. I did decrease the amount of oil as others recommended and it was just fine (used 3-4 TBS). I don't think I would have topped it off with the marinade before baking. 

I wish I would have checked a few other reviews before I made it, I would have pulled it out at 25 min, not kept for 35+.

I will try again and use less salt and maybe dill instead of parsley as others have suggested.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2491881.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious and easy recipe. I  tried the recipe 4 times already and my salmon always tastes great.

Here are some suggestions:
- I think the recipe calls for too much oil, I decrease the amount of oil to half and still get a moist piece of salmon
- Sub some of the oil with melted butter, yum!
- For big portions (or even small ones like 2 pieces of salmon), I add the fish with the marinade to a baking dish. I cover the dish with aluminum foil and leave fish to marinade before baking.
- You can always unwrap the foil before the fish is fully cooked and brown it (I use the broiler in my oven) , great color and crunch on the top of the fish and without overcooking.

text:
I think the recipe is exceptional and it has been a staple of mine for a while. I use the suggested amount of oil and it works well for me. I don't add as much of the oil into the foil to put in the oven, but I do make sure to take all the herbs and garlic that are chopped in there and place them on top of the salmons in the packet. 

The packet should be completely sealed. Dry fish might be due to a leak in the packets or not including enough marinade. I cut 10 minutes off the last fish I made with this recipe as it was a significantly smaller portion. Regardless, for me it always comes out moist and practically falling apart with flakiness. 

I usually serve it with rice and parmesan asparagus. Divine.

5

text:
This is a very very good recipe.  I made it exactly, however, I just baked it uncovered in a baking dish for about 40 minutes.  I had a small piece of salmon...a tiny bit less than a pound.  I used the exact measurements and took off the skin.  Served with couscous and laid the fish on top and grilled asparagus on the side.  It was so easy and delicious.  It will be made a few times a month.  The sauce it creates is so good drizzled over everything.

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sooooooo good. I made a few changes after reading the reviews. I only had one half pound salmon filet, so I halved the marinade recipe BUT used only 2.5T olive oil, 2t lemon juice and cut salt and pepper down to 1/4t. I kept the amount of garlic the same at 2 cloves minced and also threw in a couple pinches of dill. Marinated the filet in a ziplock bag in the refrigerator for a little over an hour and then baked it at 375 for 20 minutes in a glass dish (no foil). IT WAS PERFECTION. So moist and flavorful! The marinade added a great flavor but didn't overpower the salmon.  This is definitely going to become a regular dish for me.

text:
Overall it was easy and delicious - I substituted garlic scapes for the garlic (because they're in season and I'd never used them before) and used a little less oil.  I used wild Pacific salmon filets from our local organic store - they are pretty thick but I only did 20 minutes in the oven.  It was well-done, but I think next time I'd try maybe 18 minutes because I like it a little more medium.  Cooking fish filets 35 minutes is way way too long!

country:
None
text:
My first attempt at salmon and it came out great. As everyone knows salmon can be pricey so messing it up is not an options. I was a little intimidated at first but have made this recipe a few times now. I find the stated cooking time can be a bit much so I only bake for about 25 mins, when it flakes it's done. Also I marinate in a glass dish covered in foil and bake it that way versus wrapping the salmon in foil. I have done it both ways(foil and covered dish) and find I like the covered dish better for some reason. Definitely easy and delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe following the instructions, but also added 1/2 tsp of both dill and garlic powder. Because I am not much of a fish lover, I feared that the marinade wouldn't be enough flavour; so before baking, I coated the the fillets in a breadcrumb/pecan/dill/lemon pepper crust. I baked the salmon fillets in a half-open fool envelope, meanwhile I whipped up a garlic-lemon-dill sauce (milk/cornstarch/garlic powder/lemon pepper/dill). The end result was excellent. I'm glad that I coated the salmon and whipped up a sauce. I served the fish with white rice. Verdict: Would make again

country:
None
text:
This dish was so easy to make and it tasted incredible. The only note I would make is to make sure you use the thick pieces of salmon from up towards the head versus the thinner ones from closer to the tail. The thin pieces tend to taste a little watered down in comparison to the thicker ones. This recipe is spot on if you use the thick piece.

text:
I thought this was a great recipe.  I don't like fish, so I made it for my husband and a couple of friends.  They loved it.  I decided to try it, and found it palatable -- a far, far cry from how I imagined salmon would taste.  Oh, I did cover it with parchment paper cut to fit the inside of the glass 9 x 12 dish I cooked it in, because I was out of foil.  I tried to get the skin off the 2 lb. slab of salmon I cooked, and couldn't do it.  It came off very easily after it was cooked, though.

text:
This was extremely simple to prepare and my boyfriend and I thought it was fantastic...served with rice and asparagus.  I followed the recipe but also added minced garlic, black pepper and dill to the marinade...FANTASTIC!  My salmon filets were larger, I cooked them in the glass dish covered with foil and it still only took 25 minutes of cook time (the last 10 minutes I uncovered it). This will definitely make it's way into my dinner rotation and will make eating more fish an attainable goal! Yum!

None
text:
Made with all ingredients, but reduced the salt and pepper to probably 1/4-1/2 tsp at most. Cut olive oil to 3 tablespoons and I'm glad I did because 6 would have been way too much!! I used 3 5oz salmon steaks (boneless & skinless), cooked at 375 for 40 minutes and let sit wrapped in the foil on top of the stove for 10 minutes while I cooked my asparagus in the oven. They were cooked perfectly. I'm not a huge fan of salmon, but this was actually pretty good. I have saved it in my recipe box and will definitely be making again.

country:
None
text:
I replaced 2/3 of the oil (and all the salt of course) with a slightly smaller amount of soy sauce. I thought it was maybe a little too oily even then but that did help a lot. It cuts down the oil significantly and adds more flavor without overpowering the fish. If you're concerned about the sodium or MSG there are brands and flavors with less or none.

I made a lot of servings and it went over well, all getting eaten that night. I baked it all on a cast iron grill pan at a higher temperature for less time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So I made this recipe for my boyfriend and he LOVVEEED IT. I followed other people's suggestions and went half on the oil, and salt. I added some tarragon, extra garlic, and lemon juice some garlic powder, paprika, creole seasoning and ground cayenne pepper to give it some pizazz. I also used fresh basil and dried parsely. Before baking, I put a few thin lemon slices on the salmon along with some butter. I kept a good eye on the fish so that I would not over cook it, I believe I cooked it for about 20 mins on 375. It came out flakey and moist. I served it with white rice, and sauteed garlic butter green beans.It was soo good my boyfriend told me to add it to my list when I cook for him. I felt flattered, will definently make this again

yum! i tried this tonight and it turned out great! i used 4 cloves of garlic, and added some dill weed. i cooked my large fillet of salmon for 45 minutes and it was cooked perfectly! (this is the first time i've cooked salmon properly - i've always over cooked it but not this time!!) i also made basmati rice and steamed asparagus w/lemon juice and fresh parmesan and salt & pepper! my family loved dinner!
thx for sharing this easy to do recipe! much appreciated.

text:
This is the best salmon that I have ever made.  I am not a big salmon lover but this was absolutely delicious.  Even my 2 year old ate this, and he can be picky.  I did make a few changes...  I used closer to a pound of salmon, reduced the olive oil to 2 tablespoons, reduced salt to 1/2 teaspoon, and used 1/2 tablespoon of dried parsley since I did not have fresh. It made the perfect amount of marinade.  I definitely recommend removing the skin so that the salmon does not have a fishy flavor. I will definitely be making this again.

Finally!! I really don't like salmon at all, so I've never really made it, even though my husband loves it.  I've always wanted to like it, it is so healthy for you, but I've never found a piece I liked.  This recipe is perfect, I actually loved it!  Took some other posters suggestions and decreased the olive oil to 3 tbsp and upped the lemon juice to 3 tbsp, I also doubled the garlic, but left all else the same and I thought it was delicious!! Baked at 400 for 40 minutes(thick filets)in a glass dish with foil over the top and even my 18 month old very picky son was devouring it.  I will DEFINITELY make this again!!

text:
This salmon is excellent and I will make it at least once a month.

My only issue is that it was emailed to me (from All Recipes) as 1 of 5 "no fuss dinners" and then I saw that the total time from start to finish was 2 hours.  When you get home from work at 6:00 pm,  2 hours later is late to feed your family (adding 1/2 hour more because I am not going to start cooking the second I walk in the door). There are plenty of fresh fish recipes that don't take this long.  I would certainly do this on a Saturday or Sunday.  This is not a slight against the author but perhaps All Recipes needs to realize that "no fuss" is certainly under 2 hours (Monday to Friday)

text:
Absolutely loved this recipe and it was very easy to make, especially for a "novice" cook. I made the following changes and it really turned out well! I ended marinating the entire salmon fillet (1.18 lbs) instead of individual 6 oz fillets, for 15 minutes instead of an 1 hr because I was short on time. I followed the ingredients to a tee, with the exception of using dried parsley instead of fresh parsley. I also topped the fillet with fresh onions, while marinating in the refrigerator. I covered the entire fillet and cooked it for about 40 minutes. I also added 1 tablespoon of butter on top of the fillet the last 10 minutes of cooking it...and Voilà! It was nothing but pure goodness! My husband loved it as well...and he is an avid cook!

text:
This recipe is quick, easy and incredibly delicious! As others suggested, I used 2 tbsp of olive oil and kept all other measurements the same. It made the perfect marinade. I sprayed a baking dish, put the salmon in dish skin down, spread marinade on top, covered with foil and refrigerated for about half an hour. I cooked it in the oven as directed (was done perfectly in 25 min) except went directly from fridge to oven with the foil still covering dish. (I did not individually wrap the salmon in foil.) Everyone loved it! Can't wait to make it again.

text:
No need to marinate. Place salmon fillets on parchment paper on baking sheet. Brush with olive oil, sprinkle with purchased salmon seasoning, or lemon juice, dill and paprika. Bake in 400F oven for approximately 10 mins.  Do not overcook -it gets dry and strong tasting.

userID:
9836908
Display Name:
Caroline Reed Vipperman
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
27
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4340904.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe about 5 times now, and it is consistantly delicious. The last time I used it was with one large fillet (1.79 lbs). My advice for anyone who is using a large fillet similar to the one I used is to line a cookie sheet with aluminum foil and use that for both marinading and baking. Also, divide the total number of ounces in your fillet by 6 (the serving size used for this recipe) and use the total as your number of servings (16 ounces = 1 lb, 18 ounces /6 ounces=3  servings). Using that formula my fillet turned out most excellently and was a big hit with everyone in my family.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-08-23T19:30:38.57

I don't eat fish so my rating is based on a super picky husband who LOVED it!  The only thing I changed was I added a little bit of dill.  The only negative comment my husband made was, "This was GREAT but I think next time maybe leave off the dill."    I suggest preparing exactly as it says. It was cooked perfectly, and turned out pretty and flaky.
I did as another suggested and put a big piece of foil in the glass dish, THEN added the oil and other ingredients. I wrapped it up while in the dish, cooked it and the dish comes out clean. Great idea and easy clean up.

My husband called it amazing!  I had no dried basil so I used dill.  I did have some Mrs. Dash Tomato Basil Sprinkle, I used a dash of that with a bit of salt and pepper. I followed the baking instructions and hands down, best salmon I've ever had!

text:
wonderful. i made a few adjustments though... I used a teaspoon of butter instead of oil, and microwaved it for 30 seconds with 2 cloves of garlic crushed into it. Then I added the rest of the ingredients to the butter and garlic,and poured over the fish... I didn't even need to marinade. When you seal the garlic into the foil like that it really infuses the fish - doesn't have a choice really! My kids LOVED it. We've vowed to make it every week. Delicious!

text:
Just my made this salmon for the first time and it was truly amazing. One of the best salmon dishes I have ever had - and I converted my boyfriend, who previously would not eat fish. He liked this!  On suggestions below, I also used only 3 T olive oil, and omitted the parsley.  I added some dill.  I did not have time to marinate, so I drizzled the marinade on top of the fish in a glass baking dish, covered w foil and baked at 375 for 20 minutes. Also made white rice and poured the leftover marinade from the baking dish on top of the rice.  It was incredible.

text:
Perfect tasting salmon, but MASSIVE amount of olive oil (360 calories per serving of oil).  I so much enjoyed it earlier this evening, but didn't realize how much oil was there.  Agree with other reviewers and will try something along their modifications --- much less oil, perhaps a wine/clear base added, additional lemon juice (I love lemon).  35 minutes was more than enough for my 3 servings (6 ounces per fillet).  I hate to report this, but I feel slightly nauseous now (4 hours later), likely due to the high fat content (sorry).   But this will be perfect with, say, 1 or 2 tsp of oil with perhaps a little butter (or none at all) --- I'll have to experiment!!!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was delicious, followed the instructions and tweaked it as the other reviewers suggested. 2T olive oil, 1T melted butter, 3T lemon juice, halfed the salt and I even added lemon slices on top of the salmon before sealing it in aluminium bags before putting it in the oven. Came out moist and juicy(lots of juice to pour on the rice bed). Only baked it for 10 mins though. 35 mins seems too long. Didn't have parsley but will give that a try next time. I only gave it 4 stars because I put 2 garlic cloves which gave it a nice mild taste, though next time I'll double it for a stronger flavour. Was worried we put too much garlic initially but it still turned out very well. My BF who's not much of a fish person loved it and had double helpings. Will definately make it again next time. Thanks. =)

text:
I was in a hurry so I bought the salmon at Trader Joe's and defrosted 1/2 way. Marinated until it defrosted (about 1/2 the time) in powdered garlic, onion powder, salt, pepper, and fresh squeezed lemon juice of one lemon. I baked for 35 min, but thing 30 would have been *perfect*. Super easy, delicious, and healthy- will make again!

text:
I wasn't sure if i'd like this or not, because I'm not a big fan of basil - but this actually was fantastic. I lowered the olive oil, upped the garlic (considerably), used sea salt & lowered that as well. Next time I'll decrease the basil as well (it wasn't overpowering by any means, but it masked the garlic flavor a bit too much). I marinated it for about 6hrs, baked in my toaster oven and it was super delish! I tend to fly by the seat of my pants while cooking, and I adapt recipes a lot to my own liking .... but really, you can't go wrong w/this recipe. Everyone scarfed - and I wish I would have made more :)  On another note, I made wild rice as one of the sides .... ugh, *I* found it foul!! Growing up w/mostly white rice, I'm not surprised ... but if someone has a tip/trick to make that stuff not so nasty, I'd appreciate it. Maybe a good way to season it up, or a specific brand they like - feel free to pass along some input. XOXO

Great recipe; I too lowered the amount of olive oil, probably to about 4 Tbs. This was my first time making salmon because my husband isn't a fan of seafood (what is wrong with him?!). However, he was recently diagnosed with a vitamin b12 deficiency so we decided it was time for him to start eating fish. He actually really liked it! Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
This was the first time I've ever cooked salmon and it was delicious!  I doubled the recipe and made these changes (these are the total amounts I used): 4T oil, 2T melted butter, 4T lemon juice, several dashes dried dill, 2tsp dried parsley, 1 tsp salt (the other ingredients listed in the recipe were simply doubled).  I also skinned the fish before marinating it. When it was ready to bake I just covered the glass dish with foil and popped it in the oven. Delicious! Poured the extra sauce over a side of Orzo and vegetables.  Next time I may further reduce the oil/butter combo, and maybe the lemon (but just a tad).

Thank you for sharing this recipe!

This is such an easy fool proof way to impress anyone.  It is also versatile in that you could use butter instead of Olive Oil and I didnt even measure out the ingredients, I just guesstimated.  I did use crushed garlic and added a little more then called for.  I have used this with halibut and white salmon as well.  It will be hard for me to make salmon or halibut any other way from now on.

text:
Love this recipe.  I too modified it:
For 4 pieces of salmon:  4 teaspoons of crushed garlic.  Used cilantro instead of parsley. Used 1 tablespoon lemon juice and 1 tablespoon of lime juice. Used only 1/4 teaspoon of salt and 2 tablespoons of canola oil/olive oil blend.
Used a stone baking dish and baked at 400 for 15 minutes and broiled for 5 minutes.
Smells delicious and tastes fantastic!

text:
Very good alternative recipe for salmon! I had a 2 lb. fillet and basically tripled everything except oil, salt and pepper.  I only used 1/4 cup oil, salmon is an oily fish anyway and used 1 1/2 tsp. salt and 1/2 tsp. pepper plus about 1 big tablespoon chopped, fresh basil.  Put it all in a big ziplock to marinade for an hour.  Thank you for something different to do with my salmon!

I loved this, and so did my guests. It was a nice light flavor to add to the salmon- not at all overpowering. I just kinda winged it on the olive oil (didn't use light),  probably did 4 tablespoons instead of six. I only did this because I didn't want it to turn out too oily. text:
I didn't actually follow the recipe as written but it turned out incredible anyway.  I just didn't have all the ingredients.  I used dried seasonings & lemon pepper because that was all I had on hand.  The salmon I bought was still frozen with the skin on one side so I seasoned it (let it thaw & marinade at the same time) overnight in the fridge.  Added rosemary and a bit of dill along with extra fresh minced garlic.  The next day when I cooked it wrapped tightly in the foil all the flavors had seeped into the fish and it had an outstanding flavor.  Next time I'd love to try the recipe as written.  I'm sure it's wonderful.

I was going to give this a four because I thought the texture was a little iffy (but otherwise tasted good), but the reaction of my husband persuaded me otherwise. He's normally a quiet, "shovel-it-down" eater, but he couldn't stop saying how great it was! I baked it for a few more minutes uncovered to make it more firm, and I may reduce the salt next time. This is definately going on my dinner rotation.

text:
Fabulous recipe, takes a lot of abuse and still comes out great.  I've made it a few times and now mix the marinade ingredients in the bottom of a glass baking dish (I also prefer to add a T of melted butter) and add the fish flesh down for about 30 minutes and then bake with tin foil over the baking dish. So easy and delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe! I have never been able to cook an edible piece of fish, but this turned out perfect -- moist, flaky, and delicious! My boyfriend, who's used to his mother's fine cooking, even asked me to make it again. I marinated each fillet in a ziplock baggie, massaging them every 15 minutes. I served it over steamed rice with onions and red bell peppers sauteed in olive oil, salt, pepper, and crushed red peppers over medium heat for 15-20 minutes. And I used a garlic-flavored extra virgin olive oil for the fish and the veggies because we've always liked garlic. This is definately becoming a staple recipe for me!

text:
We really enjoyed this salmon although we increased the recipe by one third because we used two 8 ounce fillets.  The only other change we made was to leave the skin on (we had our fish monger remove the scales obviously).  We will definitely make this again as the fish was VERY moist and tender - very nice, mildly flavoured marinade.
